p: The Solanaceae family is a monophyletic dicot group, which contains widely cultivated crops with individual species serving as a food source, as a source of bioactive molecules or as ornamentals [ 1]. Species belonging to this family, such as the potato ( Solanum tuberosum), tomato ( S. lycopersicum), pepper ( Caspicum annuum) or tobacco ( Nicotiana tabacum), are grown on all continents with temperate or tropical climates and are commonly found in many households worldwide [ 2]. Beside crops, medicinal plants used for alkaloids production can be found in the same family, e.g., deadly nightshade ( Atropa belladonna), black henbane ( Hyoscyamus niger) and jimson weed ( Datura stramonium). Plants from the Solanaceae family have also played an important part in genetic research over the last hundred years [ 1]. Cultivated Solanaceae species often grow side by side within the same ecosystem with wild species of the family, some of which are frequent weeds [ 3]. Under all complex cultivation contexts, Solanaceae plants are exposed to infectious pathogens, including viruses.
